title: Will an NBA Finals series decide a 2020 NBA Champion before 15 October 2020?
preds: Increasing the likelihood that this will go ahead from my first forecast because the first final match has already been played - no interruptions to the schedule yet.
The NBA bubble has been very effective. Unlikely that this series goes 7 games with Game 7 scheduled for 10/13.

The schedule for the best-of-seven finals games series is already published, the decisive game 7 is scheduled for 13 October 2020, so well ahead of the closing date of this question. If nothing drastic happens to the teams, or to the society (which would question the value of sports for the time being), there will be a 2020 champion on 13 October, or, if they have to push one of the games by one or two days (very unlikely), on 15 October 2020 at the very latest. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_NBA_playoffs#NBA_Finals:_(W1)_Los_Angeles_Lakers_vs._(?)_TBD

1% chance is still reasonable. There's a chance of external problems impacting again. AND if the Lakers-Nuggets series goes to 7, game 7 of the final will be played on, not before, oct 15 (assuming there is a day gap between all matches)

The players have agreed to resume play and the finals are due to be completed 13th October 2020. The players are all in a bubble, so the risk of covid derailing the NBA isn't high at all. I've chosen to put my forecast at 80%, rather than higher as there is only a small window between the proposed end date (13th) and the closing date of this question (15th), so any further small delay will mean the champion won't be decided by the 15th October.

Looks like there has been a resolution to continue the playoffs.
https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29752941/nba-players-decide-resume-playoffs
Lakers and Clippers want to cancel the season

Twist and turns of reality... https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/nba-boycott-live-updates-lakers-clippers-vote-to-end-season-after-bucks-protest-jacob-blake-shooting/live/ For the moment, I don't think they're going to risk the whole season, even though there are heavyweights like LeBron James among the opinion leaders.

Adjusting down until the current situation becomes more clear.
https://www.nba.com/article/2020/08/26/nba-games-postponed-bucks-magic-thunder-rockets-lakers-blazers
The bubble is being kept so secure it is unlikely the virus gets in.
Since I last updated there have been 2 more weeks of 0 new cases.
season seems to be progressing and bubble working, increasing odds
Absolutely, unless some unconsidered cataclysmic event occurs such as nuclear warfare, biological weapon use, terrorist attack, ect.
There is discussion of moving the finals date earlier. Certainly well on their way to finishing on time.

Seems to be going well so far with strict measures. As they increase the number of people in the bubble through visitors that increases the risk. Although if the visitors were to cause problems they would likely pause, kick out the visitors and then resume once everybody tests negative again.
So far, with 22 teams, there has been no cases of covid yet. Quite impressive. https://www.gq.com/story/keeping-covid-outside-the-nba-bubble-truehoop
The NBA has run the bubble with minimal issues so far, and similar bubble concepts across various sports have been very successful.

With a couple of weeks since the restart behind us, and a few instances of positive cases popping up in the bubble since then, the schedule looks to be able to continue to hold, barring widespread cases impacting multiple teams
Since the bubble started there have only been 2 cases and they were both in the first week during the quarantine period... the bubble is working.
Not sure I understood correctly, but it is scheduled, I think chances are close to 100%

First week in the bubble: 2 cases
Second week: 0 cases
Third week: 0 cases
Initial forecast.  Players will sneak out, or be exposed by staff.  Season will finish, but some  games may be cancelled or delayed.
Is it possible the NBA will be the only US pro league to get it right? MLB and NFL both seem to be shambling awkwardly toward failure.

A member of resort staff will be become infected through community exposure and expose players to the virus during their pre-symptomatic period causing a suspension of games once identified while players are individually quarantined to determine if infected.
A ton has been invested into this project. However I'm concerned the safety mechanisms aren't very stringent and we may see a surge of cases, which would necessitate a shutdown or delay.

They've had very few positive tests in first 14 days of bubble and have huge financial incentives to finish the season. While the virus will get worse in winter and more people move indoors, that should be after this ends in mid-October

I think that it is slightly more probable that the season will need to be called off, in spite of the precautions.  There is always the chance the NBA could name a winner without completing the season based on some other criteria, other than winning the tournament outright.
Workers can interact with players which may increase players’ probability of contracting the virus.

I think the NBA has exhibited competent leadership and a willingness to expend the resources necessary to make the bubble work, so I'd place a low likelihood on the possibility that no champion is ultimately crowned. But if there are positive tests, especially to a whole team or a prominent player, I could see the NBA delaying for a week or two, and thereby missing the October 15 deadline. The bubble is strong, but it isn't perfect, particularly with the high case count in the surrounding areas,

No player in the bubble has coronavirus currently, and Adam Silver & Co. have put in place comprehensive action plan and SOPs for most eventualities.
The biggest risk, however, is that families will be allowed to come in after the first round I think, and they may bring the virus with them. By that time, the virus may have spread even more in the rest of the US.

Elements of the question: How will a 2020 NBA Champion be decided? Finals Series                                                                                                               85%
No NBA Champion                                                                                                    10%
Board of Governors Consensus on deciding a Champion any other way        5% If an NBA Finals does occur, will it be prior to 15 October 2020: Will an NBA Finals finish prior to 15 October 2020                                                              82%
Will an NBA Finals finish on or after 15 October, but before the end of October          15%
Will an NBA Finals finish after the end of October 2020                                                       3%
There is a high probability to have a season champion because there are enough games to make a play off season with less players involved as a way to test the Disney bubble.
Delays if CoVID gets inside the nba bubble
The bubble appears to be working. There are no cases of covid-19 inside the bubble, and the NBA's various efforts to keep it outside of the bubble appear to be working.
The NBA will do whatever it can to stay within the scheduled timeframe. But a breakout of COVID, or anything that affects star players and star teams could put that injeopardy.

If they are willing and able to start now given the disastrous current number of cases in the US, then I think it's quite likely they continue on, barring an incident of community spread within the NBA bubble.
Anticipate delays in starting playoffs because of excessive Covid-19 cases on one or more teams.

As of now, (7/23) the NBA bubble appears to be working. The latest round of testing indicated there were zero positive tests. This shows that players and team officials are taking the bubble seriously. The latest round of zero tests came in a time in which Florida, which is playing host to the bubble, has seen a sustained outbreak for the last month. It appears there are two issues that may derail the NBA. First, is that as the process moves forward, and more people are allowed inside the bubble, everyone becomes complacent and the number of positive tests increase. This would be especially damaging if several high profile athletes were hit with positive tests or opted not to play because of increased positivity rates. The second issue is outside the control of the NBA. If we see a continuation of increasing numbers in Florida an the rest of the country the NBA may come under social pressure to stop playing. This would be an issue if complaints about the number of tests teams receive become a story as local populations are unable to secure testing. To date, it appears testing shortages are not an issue but if the country sustains a second wave in the early fall, it could derail the promising gains made by the NBA.
They will find some kind of way to complete it
I do not think anything will happen significant enough to derail current scheduling
They will make it happen even if there is player attrition due to COVID.  Too much at stake.

Economic interests are leading the decisions of NBA
Unless there is catastroph (e.g., several number of Covid positives) I do think NBA will accomplish their calendar
Already had a high probability, but updating even higher for the same reasons @osbad4 gave.

Today the NBA announced that there were 0 positive tests in the 346 players who have made it into the bubble. Reports from inside the bubble have said that moving around is extremely difficult (10 minute walk even between hotels, much less getting off campus). Employees who interact with players most are getting tested every day, masks are strictly enforced.  I'm continuing to raise this given that thus far, it's working. Will let any breakout lead this prediction in the other direction.

It's been 10 days since teams arrived and only 2 cases have been reported. I was impressed with the plan the NBA had and the execution seems to be strong as well. The best time for the virus to spread was the past week while players and staff were arriving from all over the country, but it does not seem to have done so.
Continuing to get more bullish about the NBA season, especially given that it doesn't seem like any players have contracted anything while in the bubble yet.
Unlikely a full season will be concluded.

Updating from 75 to 76%. The only new information I got today is that players are using the anonymous hotline for protocol violations, which should slightly reduce the chance of the virus spreading widely enough to cancel the season.
I feel this is a safe bet. It might be ugly, but something will be decided. It'll be shocking if everything falls apart completely.
This virus is too contagious, and the plan to allow families after a few weeks will make risks even higher than they are already with several guys already trying to bring in outsiders.
Too much politically invested in the success of the bubble. ‘Normality’ will be resumed at all costs

Increasing from 70 to 75, although 2 players in the bubble tested positive they were still in quarantine. While there will inevitably be isolated cases, the NBA's stringent measures seem to be limiting the spread of the virus, though it is still early to say that with certainty.
The NBA will be cancelled before the finals due to Covid
There is money at risk so they are incentivised to complete. Other sports have returned successfully.

It is really difficult to suspend activity once it has restarted. To maintain the semblance of control, the NBA will have to treat each new case as though it is isolated, not affecting the league. Until there are guidelines for when to shut down again, the league will continue to play as long as each team has enough players to start a game.

The current schedule has a game 7 for October 12, meaning a sweep in the finals could end the series by October 6. My belief is that if the "bubble season" resumes as planned, they will very likely finish as planned. So that 20% uncertainty is really based on what happens over the next two weeks.  Compared to other American professional leagues, I believe the NBA is taking the risks seriously. Potential delays to finishing by 10/15 would be an outbreak within the bubble. Based on testing protocols and how they are keeping teams apart, I believe that an outbreak involving multiple teams is unlikely. It is possible a team might have multiple cases, but I believe the league will stick to it's word and isolate those players, forcing a forfeit of games, if necessary.  Also, because of the planned schedule for next season (draft, free agency, training camps, and start of season by Christmas). The NBA needs to stick to it's schedule for the remainder of this season to stick to that offseason schedule. Therefore, even if their are delays or minor issues, I believe the response would be to compress the current schedule (possibly reducing playoffs from 7 to 5 game series) to ensure that it finishes on time.

As of now 18 players/staff currently have COVID-19, but none of them traveled to Orlando, and the last positive results were on July 9th.  This is encouraging as the MLS's problems began shortly after teams arrived. Furthermore, the NBA's protocols are more stringent than the MLS's. The MLS already has at least 22 cases in their bubble and despite 2 teams dropping out, their season is continuing. https://www.reddit.com/r/nba/comments/hfinjk/discussion_running_list_of_confirmed_covid19/
https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29321006/in-documents-nba-details-coronavirus-testing-process-orlando-campus-life
https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/07/10/mls-bubble-is-massive-undertaking-how-it-fares-will-tell-us-lot-about-sports-return/

Cases have been rising in the 1-2 months since the reopening of most States. While hospitalizations are lower than expected, more municipalities are enacting public masking requirements. Cases will continue to rebound through the fall and most professional sports will cancel their seasons.  This includes the NBA.

Will the NBA resumption successfully continue till the finals? I say yes 80%.
If so, will there be a delay? I say 0%. If there is a delay, then it will be the end of the season so full overlap with the first question above.

Starting out sort of in the middle. There’s a lot riding on the NBA getting the finals completed on time due to the following season. Trying to imagine what situations delay the finals: 1. Players get sick and regular season games get delayed - no as long as the playoffs start on time
2. Random players get sick during the playoffs - no
3. A significant population of a playoff team gets sick - YES
4. The regular season doesn’t start on time - YES I think once we get to the playoffs, teams are going to try and get their players buckled down to stay healthy, there will be a lot of peer pressure amongst players, etc.  I’m weighing the odds down by the two YES situations. Even when catastrophic injuries happen (every year) to key players, games don’t get delayed. They’ll try to keep things moving.
Covid-19 will make too many players grievously ill and the NBA will not have a Champion.

Chances of no covid-19 flareups within league that necessitate a delay to schedule if not entire season being called off seem highly likely in next 4 months, particularly as season moves into fall with expected resurgence of virus and overall approach of FL in treating virus (bubble unlikely to be airtight)

The number of positive COVID cases will play a major part in the league and players decision to continue with playing a playoff season. In addition, the 90+ days of isolation for the players may prove to be too much...
Dialing down a bit after further consideration on other questions under this challenge.

Outbreaks are inevitable once asymptomatic players are quarantined together. At the first sign of an outbreak, elite players, especially young elite players, will have to re-assess whether this one season is worth potentially risking their future potential, especially considering the long-term health effects of COVID-19 are unknown. Have a series championship without elite players present will not be a true "NBA Championship." It would be a "best of the rest" championship, which would make the league out to be unsympathetic to their players' health concerns, and out of touch with the best interests of their players' legacies.
Else where in the world already got sports going.......
I think the season will be cancelled again due to covid-19 infections (players & team/league staff).
You can't sell the gear if you don't have a season.
If they need to cancel some games, they have to reschedule. Finals are being planned from 30/09-12/10. 4 days later seems probable, imo.
LA Lakers are on the way to win the title.

Quite a few players have already opted out because they do not want to get the virus and/or transmit it to family members. Players will, of course, get the virus-- they already are. As more players get the virus, more will opt out and leave. Enough will leave to make finishing this experiment unlikely.
Expect that only major disruption (e.g. substantial number of players testing positive, large number of positives on a single team) would prevent completion of planned games.

Step 1: Get all the players to the site.
Step 2: Keep them healthy initially.
Step 3: Actually restart the season.
Step 4: Maintain the protocols for the duration.
Step 5: Keep a substantial majority of players from getting sick. A lot can go wrong between now and the final series, and the virus has a sneaky way of undermining one’s belief that we humans can keep it under control. I’m waiting until we actually get through Step 3 to increase the probability of “yes.”
They have to wrap up by then to free the fan base up for a pre election return to the streets. Nothing like a post win celebration to start it off.

Starting at an extreme affirmative. If they are planning a season, they are planning a series (of at least three.)
I'll whittle this down later.
How many games make a "series"?   I suppose at least three.  Odds are they will figure out a way to have a championship series of at least three games, even if there are no games preceding it.
While I anticipate spread, I project that it will be controlled by the 180 pages of rules, meaning most of the players will not get infected.
